articles.headline: Suburban Women Find Little to Like in Donald Trump’s Debate Performance
articles.snippet: Undecided women in Philadelphia’s suburbs, a crucial voting bloc, said Mr. Trump had not only failed to win them over but in many cases had repelled them.
articles.abstract: Undecided women in Philadelphia’s suburbs, a crucial voting bloc, said Mr. Trump had not only failed to win them over but in many cases had repelled them.
articles.lead_paragraph: WEST CHESTER, Pa. — Donald J. Trump badly needed to make an impression on women like Nancy Groux in Monday’s presidential debate. She is an undecided Republican who hungers for change in Washington and thinks business experience would be an asset in the Oval Office.

articles.headline: Chinese Tourists Pump Cash Into a Hot Destination: China
articles.snippet: Chinese tourists took four billion domestic trips in 2015, twice as many as in 2010 and many more than the 122 million trips abroad, the government said.
articles.abstract: Chinese tourists took four billion domestic trips in 2015, twice as many as in 2010 and many more than the 122 million trips abroad, the government said.
articles.lead_paragraph: SANYA, China — When Stephan Stoss arrived here six years ago, little more than lush foliage lined the roads leading to the 492-room Hilton where he is now general manager.

articles.headline: Why So Many Children Are Being Killed in Aleppo
articles.snippet: Among the roughly 250,000 people stuck in the insurgent redoubt in northern Syria are 100,000 children, the most vulnerable victims of intensified bombings.
articles.abstract: Among the roughly 250,000 people stuck in the insurgent redoubt in northern Syria are 100,000 children, the most vulnerable victims of intensified bombings.
articles.lead_paragraph: They cannot play, sleep or attend school. Increasingly, they cannot eat. Injury or illness could be fatal. Many just huddle with their parents in windowless underground shelters — which offer no protection from the powerful bombs that have turned east Aleppo into a kill zone.

articles.headline: Furor Over Drug Prices Puts Patient Advocacy Groups in Bind
articles.snippet: Many groups ostensibly on the side of patients find themselves conflicted by the millions they receive from the pharmaceutical industry.
articles.abstract: Many groups ostensibly on the side of patients find themselves conflicted by the millions they receive from the pharmaceutical industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: Public anger over the cost of drugs has burned hot for a year, coursing through social media, popping up on the presidential campaign, and erupting in a series of congressional hearings, including one last week over the rising price of the allergy treatment EpiPen.

articles.headline: Shimon Peres, an Enduring Pillar From Israel’s Founding Era, Dies at 93
articles.snippet: Mr. Peres helped build up his country’s military might, then worked as hard to establish peace with Israel’s Arab neighbors.
articles.abstract: Mr. Peres helped build up his country’s military might, then worked as hard to establish peace with Israel’s Arab neighbors.
articles.lead_paragraph: Shimon Peres, one of the last surviving pillars of Israel’s founding generation, who did more than anyone to build up his country’s formidable military might, then worked as hard to establish a lasting peace with Israel’s Arab neighbors, died on Wednesday in a Tel Aviv area hospital. He was 93.

articles.headline: Wells Fargo to Claw Back $41 Million of Chief’s Pay Over Scandal
articles.snippet: The move against John G. Stumpf is one of the first times since the 2008 financial crisis that a company’s chief executive has been forced to give up pay.
articles.abstract: The move against John G. Stumpf is one of the first times since the 2008 financial crisis that a company’s chief executive has been forced to give up pay.
articles.lead_paragraph: Wells Fargo announced on Tuesday that it would claw back compensation valued at $41 million from its embattled chairman and chief executive, John G. Stumpf, as the financial consequences of the scandal over illegally created sham accounts at the bank reached the executive suite.

articles.headline: Defending Against Hackers Took a Back Seat at Yahoo, Insiders Say
articles.snippet: Clashes over costs and fears that security measures would chase away customers hobbled Yahoo’s efforts, leading to the 2014 breach of 500 million users.
articles.abstract: Clashes over costs and fears that security measures would chase away customers hobbled Yahoo’s efforts, leading to the 2014 breach of 500 million users.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Six years ago, Yahoo’s computer systems and customer email accounts were penetrated by Chinese military hackers. Google and a number of other technology companies were also hit.
articles.byline: By Nicole Perlroth and Vindu Goel

articles.headline: New Debate Strategy for Donald Trump: Practice, Practice, Practice
articles.snippet: Advisers plan to more rigorously prepare him for his next debate with Hillary Clinton, but whether he is open to meticulous preparation is a major concern.
articles.abstract: Advisers plan to more rigorously prepare him for his next debate with Hillary Clinton, but whether he is open to meticulous preparation is a major concern.
articles.lead_paragraph: Campaign advisers to Donald J. Trump, concerned that his focus and objectives had dissolved during the first presidential debate on Monday, plan to more rigorously prepare him for his next face-off with Hillary Clinton. They intend to drill the Republican nominee on crucial answers, facts and counterattacks, and coach him on ways to whack Mrs. Clinton on issues even if he is not asked about them.
articles.byline: By Patrick Healy, Ashley Parker and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: More Wealth, More Jobs, but Not for Everyone: What Fuels the Backlash on Trade
articles.snippet: Trade is under attack in much of the world, because economists failed to anticipate the accompanying joblessness, and governments failed to help.
articles.abstract: Trade is under attack in much of the world, because economists failed to anticipate the accompanying joblessness, and governments failed to help.
articles.lead_paragraph: ROTTERDAM, the Netherlands — For as long as ships have ventured across water, laborers like Patrick Duijzers have tied their fortunes to trade.

articles.headline: A High-Stakes Bet: Turning Google Assistant Into a ‘Star Trek’ Computer
articles.snippet: Google is threatened by the decline of web search, so it’s making a bold bet on what comes next: an all-knowing digital helper.
articles.abstract: Google is threatened by the decline of web search, so it’s making a bold bet on what comes next: an all-knowing digital helper.
articles.lead_paragraph: Google is one of the most valuable companies in the world, but its future, like that of all tech giants, is clouded by a looming threat. The search company makes virtually all of its money from ads placed on the World Wide Web. But what happens to the cash machine if web search eventually becomes outmoded?
